column1: '''''El hobito''''' was the first translation into Spanish of [[J.R.R. Tolkien]]'s ''[[The Hobbit]]''. It was published in [[1964]] in Argentina.<ref>{{HM

On [[3 July]] [[1962]], [[Alina Dadlez]] sent Tolkien a copy of letter from the Argentinian publisher Compañia General Fabril Editora, concerning a Spanish translation of ''The Hobbit''. Tolkien [[Letter to Alina Dadlez (20 July 1962)
column2: replied]] on 20 July to Dadlez, sending her comments about how to translate specific words — suggesting the form ''hobitos'' for ''[[hobbits]]''. Dadlez forwarded Tolkien's comments to the publisher in Argentina, and wrote to Tolkien again on 17 September: the publishers point out that since ''h'' is mute in Spanish, perhaps the form ''jobitos'' could be used. Tolkien [[Letter to Alina Dadlez (19 September 1962)
column3: replied]] on 19 September, saying that he still prefers ''hobitos'': "I am sure many hobbits drop their ''h''s like most rural folk in England".<ref>{{CG

column1: ''El hobito'' was apparently not very successful since only one edition was published. A second Spanish translation did not appear until 1982 (''El Hobbit'', published by Minotauro).<ref name=TL>{{webcite

column1: Tolkien received a few copies of ''El hobito'' from the publisher in Argentina, and apparently gave one to his wife [[Edith Tolkien
column2: Edith]]. A copy is known to have been signed by Tolkien on the title page, including a dedication in Spanish: "para Edita querida R" ("to [my] dear Edith[,] R[onald]"<!-- Freely translated by User:Morgan -->). After Tolkien's death, his eldest son Father [[John Tolkien]] gave the book to Father Antonio Quevedo in September 1973.<ref name=TL/>
